content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Though most won't be able to solve it in under 5 minutes, top Clashers would be able to (when focused), and the challenge is very much real-world logic, as I noted in the comments.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice clash idea, a little bit hard, but some adjustments to the tests have made it easier to spot the tricky parts.

It's a nice clash idea and solvable in 15 minutes, but I wasn't able to solve it in 5 minutes (took around 8-10 minutes). It's hard to debug problems like this, so when you have an error in your logic it can be hard to figure out the issue.

In the end, my main problem was that I was thinking of the maximum profit as being defined by the unit profit, but really it needs to be defined by the actual profit you can make from it based on how many units you can actually afford to buy that day! It's a nice touch, but can make it tricky.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: A nicely challenging clash for a change. While solving I assumed 'the worst' (I half expected that all days the same commodity would be needed, but just to be sure I assumed the possibility of every day another commodity), and I was glad to be rewarded with the fact that this bit of extra coding was required and tested.

Stub generator
* Please add a write statement.

Thanks.

For the record, I'll include the link to the original (rejected) contribution here:
https://www.codingame.com/contribute/view/10241483ac9d191f25d7ba62ac1768d29b6829

@David Augusto Villa may also consider leaving the link to this contribution as a comment to the old one.
This contribution was inspired and derived from The Shop Owner by Le Sablier.

The original author's back with their contribution now presented as a puzzle: https://www.codingame.com/contribute/view/116967b60d7e510274f91136c11f9c95d38ac0

Perhaps you may take a look at it and give them some suggestions?

Thank you for this extremely valuable feedback. I have inserted a new test case ahead of all the rest, showing as the example, where there are other items that have greater unit profit, profit ratio, or total sales amount than the best choice, which by definition has the greatest total profit and so results in the highest balance, over just one day. I can't promise that it will be under 5 minutes with such an error, but hopefully at least this could make debugging a lot easier, being ironed out much sooner and not in the thicket of later test cases.

I think that's a good idea, but if I were you I'd make that test case even clearer with perhaps just 2 different commodity options to choose from. Currently it's perhaps still not so obvious where the final profit of 55 from one day has come from. With only 2 options, it can be a lot easier to see which one was chosen and backtrack the solution logic.

Sure, I'll cut it down to 3 options. Unfortunately there isn't a way to get everything down to one alternative option for all the erroneous measures that someone might apply. In particular, a player might suspect that the total sales for the day would correspond with the highest final balance, but this is not true if the costs are relatively lower for a smaller sales amount. I know that's not the problem you ran into, but it's conceivably an easy mistake to make.

I just got this in a clash now (Shortest mode), and wasn't able to solve it... I got 80% but couldn't get the last 2 tests to work. It's very hard to debug in-clash, because you have no idea what's going wrong.

I made sure to decrease the quantities as I bought them (and sold them to the street), but for some reason my answers for the last 2 tests are just wrong. "Three weeks" => 697 instead of 845, "One month" => 1836 instead of 1935. V7 => 543, V8 => 1777.

Not sure what's wrong... (apologies for the terrible code, I was golfing it as I went):

C,D,N,*A=`dd`.split.map &:to_i
D.times{a=(0...N).map{C+(A[1+x=_1*3]-c=A[x])*[C/c,A[x+2]].min}
C=a.max
i=a.index C
A[2+x=i*3]-=[C/A[x],A[x+2]].min}
p C
